questions.question: What is the Coriolis component of acceleration?

answers.c: Acceleration due to relative motion in a rotating system

explanations.a: Radial acceleration is associated with the distance from the center of rotation.
explanations.b: Tangential acceleration is due to changes in the speed along the circular path.
explanations.c: The Coriolis acceleration arises due to relative motion in a rotating system.
explanations.d: Gravitational acceleration is the force exerted by gravity.

questions.question: Which of the following components does not contribute to total acceleration in a rotating system?

explanations.a: Centripetal acceleration is required for circular motion.
explanations.b: Gravitational acceleration is not part of the system's rotation, so it does not contribute.
explanations.c: Tangential acceleration arises due to changes in speed along the circular path.
explanations.d: Coriolis acceleration is caused by the rotation of the reference frame.

questions.question: In which direction does the Coriolis acceleration act?

answers.c: Perpendicular to both radial and angular velocity

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration is not aligned with the radial velocity.
explanations.b: It is not opposite to the radial velocity.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration is perpendicular to both radial and angular velocity.
explanations.d: It does not act along the axis of rotation.

questions.question: What factor causes the Coriolis acceleration to arise?

answers.a: Linear motion in a non-inertial frame
answers.b: Rotational motion in an inertial frame
answers.c: Radial motion in a rotating reference frame
answers.d: Constant velocity in a rotating system

explanations.a: Linear motion in a non-inertial frame does not create Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.b: Rotational motion in an inertial frame does not produce Coriolis acceleration either.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration is caused by radial motion in a rotating reference frame.
explanations.d: Constant velocity does not produce Coriolis acceleration.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of angular velocity (Ï‰)?

explanations.a: Meters per second is the unit for linear velocity, not angular velocity.
explanations.b: Radians per second (rad/s) is the correct SI unit for angular velocity.
explanations.c: Revolutions per minute (RPM) is a non-SI unit for angular velocity.
explanations.d: Meters per second squared is the unit for acceleration, not angular velocity.

questions.question: What happens to the Coriolis acceleration when radial velocity increases?

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration increases, not decreases, with radial velocity.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration increases linearly with radial velocity.
explanations.d: Coriolis acceleration does not become zero with increasing radial velocity.

questions.question: Which physical system is most influenced by the Coriolis effect?

explanations.a: Earth's atmospheric winds are significantly influenced by the Coriolis effect.
explanations.b: Electrical circuits are not influenced by the Coriolis effect.
explanations.c: Hydraulic systems are not affected by Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.d: Stationary objects are not influenced by the Coriolis effect.

questions.question: What role does torque play in the Coriolis acceleration experiment?

answers.c: It influences the system's rotation and flow rate.

explanations.a: Torque is related to angular velocity but does not directly determine it in the Coriolis experiment.
explanations.b: Torque does not balance the radial velocity directly.
explanations.c: Torque influences the rotation and flow rate in a rotating system, affecting Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.d: Torque does play a role in the experiment.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Coriolis acceleration experiment?

answers.c: To determine the additional acceleration component in a rotating frame
answers.d: To observe the effect of gravity in a rotating system

explanations.a: The experiment is not primarily for measuring angular velocity.
explanations.b: It is not focused on tangential acceleration.
explanations.c: The primary purpose is to study the additional acceleration component caused by rotation, the Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.d: The effect of gravity is not the main focus of this experiment.
